@manish1-arista , can you link the HLD here? Also, is it backward compatible if some platforms doesn't support this new attributes?

> @manish1-arista , can you link the HLD here? Also, is it backward compatible if some platforms doesn't support this new attributes?

This is a fix for a bug introduced in PR #3509, so there is no new HLD.
The attributes already exist in the Redis DB, but were missing from the validation list, causing Orchagent to log errors. This change simply fixes that logging issue; The functional logic is already working as expected.

@rajshekhar-nexthop  not seeing the exact repro steps in the issue. Can you share what are the sequence of steps you followed to get to this error condition

Hi @judyjoseph , thanks for looking at this. The issue shows up sporadically in our MACsec sonic-mgmt runs, mainly when we exercise profile swap / replace scenarios. Concretely, this is most often hit by the sonic‑mgmt MACsec control‑plane test: tests/macsec/test_controlplane.py::test_profile_replace

The main impact is inconsistent MACsec state and noisy teardown failures, rather than steady‑state forwarding breakage.
In the failure window we’ve seen cases where CONFIG_DB still reports a MACsec profile on the port (e.g. PORT|Ethernet0 macsec=128_XPN_SCI), but APPL_DB has no MACSEC_PORT_TABLE entry and show macsec Ethernet0 is empty. That “residual MACsec config” has caused our tests (e.g. get_macsec_attr()) to hit KeyError('enable_encrypt') during MACsec disable/profile‑swap flows.

This PR strengthens the unconfigure path by giving wpa_cli interface_remove more time (with retries) to clean up, so we avoid ending up in the inconsistent state where CONFIG_DB still shows MACsec enabled but the runtime state is already gone.
